scenario.title: Manufacturing Floor Zero
scenario.description: Critical infrastructure alert on industrial control systems. A PLC hijacking attempt has been detected on the manufacturing floor.

initialAlert.title: INDUSTRIAL PROTOCOL ANOMALY [Unauthorized Modbus TCP Connection]
initialAlert.rawDetails:
Alert ID: OT-2024-11-05-90341
Source: OT Protocol Monitor
Rule: Unauthorized Modbus TCP Session Detected
Target Device: PLC-HVAC-012 (Slave PLC)
IP Address: 192.168.127.10
Network Segment: ICS/OT Network (192.168.127.0/24)
Protocol: Modbus TCP (Port 502)

Connection Details:
• Attacker IP: 192.168.127.100
• Target PLC: 192.168.127.10 (Master PLC controlling HVAC systems)
• Protocol: Modbus TCP Function Code 0x03 (Read Holding Registers)
• Connection established: 2024-11-05 03:47:18 UTC
• Anomaly: Connection does not match baseline traffic patterns

Suspicious Indicators:
⚠️ tcpkill RST packet flood detected prior to connection
⚠️ Legitimate master connection terminated abruptly
⚠️ New connection from unauthorized IP address
⚠️ No prior communication history between source and target
⚠️ Connection timing aligns with network scanning activity
⚠️ MAC address does not match authorized OT workstations

Affected Systems:
• PLC-HVAC-012: Building HVAC control system
• Critical infrastructure: Manufacturing floor environmental controls
• Potential impact: Unauthorized access to industrial control logic

Recommendation: Investigate immediately to determine if this is a PLC hijacking attempt or legitimate maintenance activity. Consider emergency shutdown of affected PLC if confirmed malicious.

questions.text: What network anomalies indicate MAC spoofing?

S3.text: VPC flow logs in S3 reveal massive ARP anomalies: 4,127 forged MAC addresses at 1,200 ARP requests/second from 192.168.127.100. This is the macof tool flooding the network with fake MAC addresses to poison ARP tables and position the attacker for the PLC hijacking attack.
transparencySteps: [Wise] Analyzing VPC flow logs: s3://security-logs-prod/vpc-flow-logs/2024/11/05/
[Wise] Searching for ARP-related anomalies in flow records...
[Wise] Found: 4,127 unique source MAC addresses from single IP (192.168.127.100)
[Wise] ARP request rate: 1,200 requests per second (normal baseline: 10/sec)
[Wise] Pattern matches macof tool signature (MAC address flooding)
[Wise] Effect: ARP table poisoning on OT network switches
[Wise] Timing: ARP flood occurred 10 minutes before PLC connection anomaly
[Wise] Assessment: Attacker positioned for man-in-the-middle attack on PLC communications

questions.text: Is this Modbus TCP connection legitimate?

OTMonitor.text: NO - This is a hijacked connection. OT Monitor's protocol analysis reveals tcpkill tool signatures: RST flood with modes -3, -5, and -9 terminated the legitimate master PLC connection, followed by a rogue Modbus TCP session from the attacker. Function code 0x03 (Read Holding Registers) was used to extract PLC configuration and logic.

[Wise] Analyzing connection sequence to PLC-HVAC-012 (192.168.127.10)...
[Wise] Detected tcpkill RST packets: modes -3 (3 RST), -5 (5 RST), -9 (9 RST)
[Wise] Legitimate master connection (192.168.127.5) terminated at 03:47:15 UTC
[Wise] Rogue connection established from 192.168.127.100 at 03:47:18 UTC
[Wise] Modbus function code analysis: 0x03 (Read Holding Registers)
[Wise] Registers accessed: 0x0000-0x00FF (PLC configuration and control logic)
[Wise] Cross-referencing with baseline traffic: Connection does not match authorized patterns
[Wise] Verdict: PLC hijacking attack using tcpkill to terminate legitimate session

questions.text: Should we trigger emergency PLC shutdown?

WISE.text: YES - EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN REQUIRED. The evidence is conclusive: (1) Nmap reconnaissance mapped 304 PLC targets, (2) macof ARP poisoning with 4,127 forged MACs positioned attacker, (3) Unauthorized attacker workstation (not in Oracle OT access list), (4) tcpkill hijacked legitimate PLC connection, (5) 12 PLCs targeted with 7 showing compromise indicators. This is an active ICS attack with potential for physical damage to manufacturing operations. Immediate isolation and shutdown required.
remediationActions: Trigger emergency shutdown for all 7 compromised PLCs
Isolate attacker IP 192.168.127.100 at OT network firewall
Disable network port for unauthorized endpoint
Initiate forensic capture of PLC configurations and ladder logic
Review and restore PLC firmware from golden images
Implement network segmentation between IT and OT networks
Notify plant operations and safety teams immediately
